senses.sense_definition: A passenger vehicle for public use that runs on tracks in the road.

examples.text: We decided to take the <w>tram</w> to the city centre instead of driving.
The <w>tram</w> stops right outside the main train station.
She waited at the <w>tram</w> stop for twenty minutes in the rain.

traits.comment: Common in UK, Australia, and Europe; usually called 'streetcar' or 'trolley' in North America.

senses.sense_definition: A vehicle consisting of a towing head and open carriages used to transport people short distances, such as in theme parks or parking lots.

examples.text: The parking <w>tram</w> brought us from our car to the park entrance.
Visitors can take a tour <w>tram</w> to see the movie sets.

senses.sense_definition: An aerial cable car suspended from a cable.

examples.text: The aerial <w>tram</w> offers spectacular views of the mountain range.
Tourists took the <w>tram</w> across the river to the island.

senses.sense_definition: A vehicle used in mines to carry coal or materials.

examples.text: The miners loaded the coal onto the <w>tram</w> deep underground.
An old rusted <w>tram</w> sat near the entrance of the abandoned mine.
They <w>trammed</w> around the city all afternoon looking for a restaurant.
She prefers <w>tramming</w> to work rather than driving in heavy traffic.

senses.sense_definition: To align a component in mechanical engineering or metalworking, particularly the spindle of a mill or drill press.

examples.text: The machinist spent time <w>tramming</w> the head of the mill to ensure it was perfectly perpendicular.
You must <w>tram</w> the machine before starting the precision cut.
